awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Active Control of Nonlinear Flow-Induced Instability of Wind Turbine Blades under Stochastic Perturbations
awd_abstract_narration:
Wind turbine blades continue to grow in length to extract more energy from the wind. This trend results in more flexible blades that are more susceptible to flow-induced instabilities, which can lead to sudden and catastrophic failures. The onset of these dynamic instabilities can be altered by the inherent uncertainties in the system, and is dangerously close to the wind turbine's designed operational speed. This poses a threat to the integrity of the system. Being able to control these instabilities is critical for the successful operation of future wind turbine blades. The goal of this project is to examine and understand appropriate methodologies to actively control nonlinear flow-induced instabilities of large wind turbine blades, considering their inherent stochastic nature. This project will support the ability to design and operate larger, more flexible wind turbine blades, which will eventually increase energy capture and reduce the cost of energy offshore wind. This research is timely since the current energy plan of the United States strongly emphasizes the need for alternative energy production from sources such as offshore wind energy. The findings of this research will be disseminated at different levels by creating new modules for different courses, hosting high school classes, and increasing research opportunities for students.

This research will consider a fully-coupled continuous fluid-structure interaction model of the flexible, rotating blades, accounting for varying blade shapes and cross-sections, as well as bending and torsional properties. We will use this nonlinear model to examine the effect of a number of non-deterministic system parameters on the onset of flow-induced instabilities, using perturbation methods as well as stochastic calculus, and to investigate strategies to actively control these flow-induced instabilities using advances in bifurcation control, probabilistic robustness and multivariable robust control. The Intellectual Merit of this project lies in a unified methodology to advance the fundamental understanding and analysis of control strategies for large wind-turbine systems, which involve the interaction of a flexible structure (the blade) and unsteady flow. These systems contain combined nonlinearities from the structure, the fluid flow around it, and the interaction between the fluid and the structure. This research is transformative because it provides fundamental insights into the underlying physics and control of nonlinear stochastic fluid-structure interaction systems with non-uniform properties, including future wind turbine blades, by combining several different areas of expertise.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Wind turbine blades continue to grow in length to extract more energy from the wind. This trend results in more flexible blades that are more susceptible to flow-induced instabilities. The inherent uncertainties in the system can alter the onset of dynamic instability (i.e., classical flutter).

This project has tackled the emerging problem of developing methods to actively control flow-induced instabilities of large wind turbine blades, considering their inherent stochastic nature. Throughout the course of this project, this issue was addressed by a novel framework that included simulation and wind tunnel experiments to efficiently and accurately predict the onset of classical flutter impacted by uncertainties.

 The objectives of the project have been achieved by implementing a fully coupled continuous fluid-structure interaction model of the flexible and rotating blades, accounting for variable blade cross-sectional shapes and cross-sections, as well as bending and torsional properties. Fundamental analysis and comprehensive derivation of the model that govern the motions of the blade were made possible using a numerical simulation procedure based on the Galerkin method and eigenvalue analysis.

 Subsequently, the deterministic model that predicts the onset of classical flutter was extended in a Monte-Carlo environment to investigate the effects of the uncertainties through stochastic analysis. The uncertainties from various sources (e.g., blade?s structural properties and aerodynamic loadings) were simulated in both pre-defined probability distributions and empirical distributions, later derived from experimental studies. In addition, surrogate models were examined as an alternative to standard environment through implementation of least squares and collocation methods, and machine learning methods (i.e., Artificial Neural Networks). Surrogate models led to computational efficiency of the stochastic analyses.

 Experimental studies were carried out by means of two different wind tunnel experimental studies. The first one was carried out to study the effects of experimental errors in static, aerodynamic force coefficients of the blades on the onset of dynamic instability. The reference blade was modeled and tested at a geometric scale 1:40 at Northeastern University small-scale boundary-layer wind tunnel to obtain the variability of lift coefficients under different experimental conditions.

 The second one was designed and conducted to examine the uncertainties in aeroelastic properties (i.e., flutter derivatives) of the blades accounting for experimental random errors. The aeroelastic wind tunnel tests were carried out with blade models at a geometric scale 1:8 in SOH Wind Engineering LLC wind tunnel (Williston, VT, USA). Experimental data were subsequently processed and analyzed using statistics and probability methods to investigate effects of experimental errors on flutter prediction.

 The project enabled the simulation and analysis of classical flutter in offshore wind turbine blades and quantified the risk of flutter failures accounting for the inherent uncertainties in the prediction of instabilities. Numerical and experimental results have demonstrated that uncertainties in the system and airflow loads can induce large variability in the flutter onset, which must be considered in the design of large wind turbine blades.

 The study promoted application of efficient and accurate investigation methods to assess wind turbine blade dynamic instability and risk of failure. Application of the methods is one step forward to achieving safe operation of wind turbine blades and to promote the use of stochastic analysis approaches in wind energy.


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Luca Caracoglia
